newsitem.title: GEORGIA: Georgian state wages to rise 20 pct - Shevardnadze.
newsitem.headline: Georgian state wages to rise 20 pct - Shevardnadze.

text.p: Georgian President Eduard Shevardnadze said on Monday wages of state employees would increase in August by 20 percent to 44.4 lari per month.
Wages of state employees in the first half of 1997 increased by 290 percent, compared to the same period in 1996, to 37 lari.
Average wages in Georgia increased in the first half of 1997 by 190 percent compared to the same period in 1996, reaching 43 lari.
"Neither 37 lari nor 44 lari is enough for our citizens but the fact of a twofold increase in one year is proof of an economic revival in Georgia," said Shevardnadze in a weekly radio address.

He said Gross Domestic Product (GDP) soared 14.8 percent in the first half of the year compared to the same period in 1996, while industrial output was up 11.8 percent and inflation was held to just 3.4 percent.
Shevardnadze said tax collection had improved in July.
Budget revenues were equal to 51.5 million lari in July, nearly three times more than last year.
"This indicator is a sign that the budget will be balanced to the end of the year," he said.
Budget revenues were 85 percent of the target in the first half of the year.
Georgia's economic growth in 1996 was the highest among former Soviet states at over 10 percent but this is partially explained by a very low base.
Most people in the small Caucasus republic still live below the poverty line.
